title: Data source: web scraping 🚫
text:
One source of data could be web scraping.

### Allowed ? NO

:warning: **Currently we don't allow this as a source** :warning: 
- because of legal reasons
- we focus on prices in physical shops

### Additional info

In the [about page](https://prices.openfoodfacts.org/about) & in the [OFF support](https://support.openfoodfacts.org/help/en-gb/29-open-prices/98-do-you-consider-scraping-prices-from-retailers-websites)
> For legal and technical reasons, we don't consider scraping prices from retailers' websites as a valid way to contribute to Open Prices. We want to make sure that the prices we collect are accurate and up-to-date, and receiving scraped prices from contributors doesn't allow us to do that.
> Price scraping is a considered option in a future version of Open Prices, but it would be done by Open Prices itself so that we can have a proof of the price based on the HTML page.

### Related issues

- https://github.com/openfoodfacts/open-prices/issues/512

author: teolemon

title: GSoC 2025 Proposal – Enhancing Price Features in the Mobile App
text:
Hi Open Food Facts community,

I’m Dayyan Chaudhri, and I’ve submitted a proposal for Google Summer of Code 2025 focused on porting and enhancing the Open Prices features in the Open Food Facts mobile app. While the current app supports basic price contributions, my goal is to expand this into a more user-friendly, trustworthy, and impactful feature that benefits shoppers in real time.

Key features I hope to implement include:
	•	Price contribution improvements (price validation, image uploading, location-based store recommendations)
	•	Visual price graphs and multi-store comparisons
	•	Credibility tools like price flagging, voting, and consistency checks
	•	Offline syncing for smoother contribution workflows

I believe this project can significantly improve accessibility to pricing data, especially in communities where the price of an item can significantly impact a whole family. If you have any feedback or ideas, I would love to hear from you. I am all about making the best contributions I can!

While this is what I have proposed, I am more than open to shifting and adapting my approach.

Best,
Dayyan Chaudhri

title: (Proposal) Compatibility with Open Beauty Facts and others
text:
### What
This is an early proposal to establish compatibility with Open Beauty Facts and others, at the most minimal cost possible.

#### Phase 0: establishing a feedback loop by deploying clones to internal
- [ ] #3923
- [ ] Add icons and visuals for all variants to the source code

#### Phase 0.5: ensuring the Dart package behaves well
- Ensure that when the base URL is on openproductsfacts.org we don't crash on lacking nutrition, ingredients… (that shouldn't actually be an issue)

#### Phase 1: tweaking core behaviours based on a forced project type
- [ ] Add a DEV mode switch to return a force project type for all products for testing/development purposes ( "off", "obf", "opf" and "opff")
- [ ] Override Open Food Facts mentions by Open X Facts based on project type
- [ ] Change the base URL based on the DEV mode project type

#### Phase 2: tweaking the UI to handle multiple project type at the same time
- [ ] Database migration to add a project type to all current products in the local database ("off")
- [ ] Add a project switcher to history (based on project type "off", "obf", "opf" and "opff")
- [ ] Add a project switcher to search (and store the type on each product opened "off", "obf", "opf" and "opff", and for any search we store locally)
- [ ] Add a project switcher to scan (and store the type on each product scanned "off", "obf", "opf" and "opff")
- [ ] Add a project switcher to Food Settings (we might want to disable customization completely for other projects, since there's no much value to bring to the users, and to save time)
- [ ] We probably do not need to add anything to lists (as they can potentially contain items from any project)
- [ ] Search results / ListView
  - [ ] Disable Eco-Score and Nutri-Score display if project != off

- [ ] Make local Open Food Facts specific behavior conditional to the product type
  - [ ] This can be done over time
- [ ] Strings
  - [ ] Add overrides to strings (let's avoid editing existing strings to avoid loosing translations)
- https://github.com/openfoodfacts/smooth-app/issues/4540

  - [ ] Compare to category should invoke the right search type, in line with the product type
  - [ ] Links to promotional content or to the user's profile should not be changed. Not enough value, and we can potentially add shortcut or additional paragraphs on the web-side
  - [ ] Add Period after Opening support for obf

### Mockup 
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/1689815/178763126-6713a6bf-d2e8-4a2d-b979-270f4dca1566.png)

title: "Need To improve flow and layout of some Pages" (Frontend Improvement)
text:
Here are some suggestions to improve the user experience based on the identified frontend bugs:

### **1) Aligning Icons and Text:  (This are minute details but important)**

- Some icons are not properly cantered with respect to text.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/302d75c8-ab96-4af8-b289-5e888931188a)
_See Create Button and + icon alignment_ 

### **2) Improving Page Flow: (Current layout is bit confusing)**

- We should maintain a clear and logical separation of different sections on the item details page to make it more user-friendly and easier to navigate. Important info should be highlighted at the starting of the section which are useful for normal user.

![image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/5464117a-8e0f-4d04-b8c6-688c3f7226fb)
_This page has too much information in small section which will confuse the user and led to less screen time._

### **3) Enhancing Home Page:**

- Consider removing the automatic opening of the scanner, which currently occupies half of the screen on the front page. This can make the front page more engaging.
- Instead we can integrate a scanner button within the search bar, allowing users to click and open the scanner only when needed. (Just like google has image search).
So that in this remaining space we can display previous searches by the user or some top searches.

author: teolemon

title: How to manage contents with a CMS and get translations done
text:
We want contents on Open Food Facts to be updated more quickly and to be more attractive.
For that we need a tool that enables content creators to do it easily. We still need contents to be massively translated.

@4nt0ineB [has done a work to have contents for open food facts in wordpress](https://github.com/openfoodfacts/openfoodfacts-server/pull/10992).
The plan was to use WPML with Crowdin to translate the contents.
But as we tested it, it does not fit our needs:
- it creates completely new file on each article modification
- it does not handle already translated items, and partial translations…

We want to explore further more what to do.

Possible ideas:
* don't use crowdin, and use wordpress for translations, managing users and so on (wikimedia does this)
* use a static site generator, and handle translations with github / crowdin
* dump html contents from wordpress and handle translations with github / crowdin

author: teolemon

title: Programming best practices
text:
After fixing a number of bugs in the Product Opener server code, I have been exposed to much of the Perl code base.  I have enjoyed the opportunity to get to know the team and to write code to contribute to the project.  However, I see a number of issues with the code as it exists now.

Here is a list of the some the things I have noticed:
- Functions are too large and complex.  Methods are often hundreds of lines of code in length and have large cyclomatic complexity with deeply nested conditional statements.  This makes code difficult to read and understand, increases the risk of bugs, lessens code reuse, limits testing and makes debugging difficult.  A good rule of thumb for method size is 15 lines.
- Object Oriented programming is not used.  Although there is a library of Perl .pm ’modules’ in the ProductOpener namespace, they only contain procedural functions.  There are a great many advantages to OO code, I won’t go into them all here.
A good book to get your feet wet on OO would be: 
[Head First Object-Oriented Analysis and Design](https://www.amazon.com/Head-First-Object-Oriented-Analysis-Design/dp/0596008678)
The classic text on OO which is always worth reading is:
[Design Patterns: Elements of Reusable Object-Oriented Software](https://www.amazon.com/Design-Patterns-Elements-Reusable-Object-Oriented/dp/0201633612/)

Perl 5 has had OO support for a while, but it is a fairly weak implementation.  It looks like the [Moose](https://metacpan.org/release/Moose) extension is the current standard for object oriented Perl, see more below.
- HTML  and Javascript are directly generated in Perl code.  This makes maintenance difficult for both server and client code.  There are a number of ways to address this, e.g. templating as in [HTML::Template](https://metacpan.org/pod/HTML::Template)
- As APIs become more popular with patterns like micro services, consider building business logic first as JSON REST services.  This will automatically provide APIs for users and then you can further decouple your front end and business logic by using a pure JavaScript front end like Angular, React, TypeScript to consume those same services.
- Code documentation is lacking, both exportable at the class and method level and inline within the code.  See issue #2203

- The advantages to implementing the above:
  - Reduced risk of occurrence of new or regression bugs.
  - Easier debugging of problems.
  - Quicker development time
  - Improved testability
  - Code reusability
  - Improved performance
  - Lower cylomatic complexity

Ways to implement these changes:
- Perl code should be written as object oriented with the Moose project.  This will immediately realize all of the advantages listed above.  Moose improves upon standard Perl OO by introducing type checking, custom types, and many other features.  While I have not used Moose myself it looks like it is the latest preferred approach to OO Perl.
- Document code, e.g. with [Perl POD](https://perldoc.perl.org/perlpod.html) as you go along while coding. Perl POD can be automatically converted to HTML and put online.
- Write tests for all code.  The test coverage in OFF is decent ( better than many projects I have worked on) but it should be a priority.
- Consider a new architecture: micro-service with pure JS front ends, etc.
- Consider a more modern language.  Java, Node, Python etc. would be options if we started this project today.

I understand the OFF is a large legacy project that was started long ago when many of these technologies did not exist and Perl was the best choice for web applications.  With the upcoming development of the self-service platform by Stephane, now might be a good time to consider implementing some of these ideas to secure a healthy future for OFF.

title: Data source: locations with OpenStreetMap (OSM)
text:
## Currently

We currently link each Price to a Location.

### Backend

The data is fetched in the backend from [Nominatim](https://nominatim.openstreetmap.org/ui/search.html).

It is defined by a unique set of `osm_id` & `osm_type`.

### Frontend

There is currently 2 ways to find a location (OSM POI)
- full-text search using [Photon Komoot](https://photon.komoot.io/)
- ID search using Nominatim

## Idea

We're looking at returning POIs given GPS coordinates (latitude & longitude). Nominatim and Photon Komoot both do NOT support this. So we'll most likely use [Overpass](https://overpass-api.de/).

Is there a unique location search engine that would allow us to search on all 3 ?
- by keyworkds/adress
- by OSM ID
- by GPS coordinates (return all shops in a radius of X meters)

## Linked issues

- #13
- https://github.com/openfoodfacts/open-prices-frontend/issues/61
- https://github.com/openfoodfacts/open-prices-frontend/issues/37

title: Evaluate ONDC protocols for aggregating pricing; *or* presenting data.
text:
Sort of #311 ; but different.

https://ondc.org/ appears to be a set of open protocols for buyers/sellers across a number of domains, including grocery. Focus on Indian market.

Seller API example:
https://github.com/ONDC-Official/seller-app-protocol - Discovery via `search`
https://github.com/ONDC-Official/seller-app-protocol/blob/master/webserver/main/request_models/retail/schema.py#L1060 < Item model, inclusive pricing. 

https://www.postman.com/speeding-zodiac-426048/ondc/collection/juqvu9i/ondc

The data might not be ODBL, but its implied much more heavily that the sellers want to be indexed.

List of participants:

title: Use case : up to date personal database of objects to lend
text:
Example : I have in my storage a brand new NGK B9ES spark plug ( 087295126110 ), not yet entered into OPF, I don't own the bike it was intended for, so no chance I'd be using it in the foreseeable future. 

I wouldn't mind making it available to lend so one person trying to troubleshoot his/her ( suspected case of foul spark plug - restarting the bike after deep storage/mothballing it ) can do so without buying a whole collection of brand new parts.

I'd need a service to build a personal list/database of stuffs I own and am willing to lend so people can search and and build their own list they're willing to lend, they look for borrowing, so they can source them from different lenders around their domicile. 

Favor/promote soft mobilty and location obfuscation/privacy when looking for matches by searching based on isochrone xx' of walking, yy' of bike riding using postcode.

Could encourage co-owning of rather expansive tools not often used by linking/connecting several users looking for the same objects ( wish list ).

title: Speed up proof & price addition
text:
### Currently

@serpico (extracted from https://github.com/openfoodfacts/open-prices/discussions/523)

> In the same spirit/related, I was adding prices yesterday based on price tag's pictures I took the same day, for reference I timed myself doing it, for 16 prices it took me 54'( with a some back and forth between OFF and Open Price webapp to create products which didn't exist, but I believe that's not the bulk of the time spent ) so it took 3'40" per price, although I'm willing to admit my workflow could be enhanced, I do use a text file from which I copy/paste the EAN for the products I track, saving some time I think.
I noticed that for a session like that, the type of proof, the location, the date and currency would be the same and the user would save time if those were once entered at the beginning of the so-called "session" and "locked", some kind of streamlined interface without all those field after initially being entered, ideally making use of the keyboard's Tab key to jump from one field to the next...maybe that's mostly what we have for the receipt mode. An additional "lockable" parameter would be EAN as opposed to category - ideally jumping straight the the EAN input box to paste the relevant EAN.
After checking what the receipt mode UI looks like it would be a variant of it, if it's deemed worth exploring I'll expand in a specific issue and share screenshot of my vision of the UI, based on the current receipt mode.
Now the question is how many user engage ( percentage of prices coming from this opposed to receipt ) in this, how much time do we save ( here's I'm thinking a stopwatch feature could be useful although it might scare away user when they realize how much time they spend for so few prices - so maybe make it bonus interface ) and is it worth the time coding this specific interface.

title: Leverage Hunger Games to crowdsource price addition (from price tag images)
text:
### What

What if we allowed any contributor to add prices from images sent over by other users ?

This would only apply to "Price tag" images, the ones taken in supermarkets or shops, where we can clearly see the EAN & the price (and ideally the product, though sometimes they are not stored at their correct place).

The image author should send the location & date. Or make it mandatory to have images with EXIF/Geoloc data ?

### How

- a new dedicated section in Open Prices web app
- a new "challenge" section in https://hunger.openfoodfacts.org

### Why

Long-term vision : 
- price tag images would only be crowdsourced (the "owner" isn't important, it's cumbersome to add these prices, we could put in some OCR/ML to speed up the price & EAN extraction)
- users would keep ownership of prices coming from receipts & GDPR requests

title: Collecting prices in supermarkets: legal or not ?
text:
# Funny story that happened while collecting proofs for open prices

I was in a supermarket earlier today and while taking pictures of price tags for OP a security guard came up to me and asked why I was taking pictures like this. I was a little taken aback so I said it was for my personal use he then said you're not allowed to, if you want to do it you have to ask and obtain permission from the management, I asked if he could show what that policy was based on, I demanded that he show at least a piece of paper to back what he was saying, he said he was gonna see with management and he left.

I went on with my shopping/snapping session and after checking out at the till I went to see him at the entrance to ask what was the verdict. He explained that it came from his colleague manning the video cameras and that 2 weeks prior a guy was in the supermarket snapping pictures here and there, said it was a different case and I had the right to do it  `¯\_(ツ)_/¯`

author: TechShooter

title: Consistent User Management UI Across Open Food Facts Tools
text:
## **Consistent User Management UI Across Open Food Facts Tools**

Goal: provide a consistent user interface (UI) and user experience (UX) for getting a “Road to KeyCloak” and managing App-specific user settings across various Open Food Facts platforms (Website with Foundation, Flutter App, React Tools like Hunger Games, Open Prices, openfoodfacts-explorer), like favorite stores, currency, dev mode settings for off-explorer…

It should try to leverage our Web Component strategy and assumes Keycloak is the central Identity Provider.

**Core Principles:**

1. **Centralized Identity & Core Data:** Keycloak is the source of truth for authentication, authorization, and core identity attributes (email, password management, sessions).  
2. **Centralized Extended Profile & Settings API:** A dedicated Open Food Facts backend API service manages user profile data *beyond* core identity (e.g., contribution stats, general preferences) and *tool-specific* settings (e.g., Open Prices currency, favorite stores). This API interacts with Keycloak and Specific tools or backends where necessary.  
3. **Web Component Library for Web UIs:** A library of customizable Lit Web Components provides the standard UI elements for user management on all web platforms (eg Account switcher, access to the page or modal containing app specific settings).  
4. **Shared Design System:** A well-defined design system dictates the visual appearance and interaction patterns, ensuring consistency even for native implementations (Flutter).  
5. **Consistent Customization:** Tool-specific settings are managed by the tools themselves but integrated visually within the structure provided by the core components.

**Implementation Details:**

1. **Backend User Profile API:**  
   * **Responsibilities:** CRUD operations for extended OFF profile data and tool-specific settings (stored appropriately, perhaps namespaced by tool). Potentially provides a endpoint for fetching combined user data (core from Keycloak \+ extended from the tool). Consistency across tools.  
2. **openfoodfacts-webcomponents** (Lit Library):  
   * **Components:** Create components like:  
     * \<off-profile-switcher\>: Shows user icon/switcher/logout for navigation bar. Inputs: link to keycloak, link to local settings, user id (to get user photo and user name)  
     * \<off-settings-layout\>: A container component providing consistent structure/navigation for settings pages.  
     * *(Other components ? Avoid stepping on KeyCloak)*  
   * **Customization via Slots:** The key to tool-specific settings.  
     * Example: \<off-settings-layout\> could have a designated \<slot name="tool-specific"\>\</slot\>.  
     * Open Prices (whether built in React or using Lit itself) would then render its own settings component (e.g., \<openprices-preferences\>) inside that slot:  
       \<off-settings-layout\>  
         \<off-profile-form slot="general"\>\</off-profile-form\>  
         \<off-account-security slot="security"\>\</off-account-security\>  
         \<openprices-preferences slot="tool-specific"\>\</openprices-preferences\>  
       \</off-settings-layout\>

     * The openprices-preferences component is responsible for its own UI *and* for interacting with the Backend User Profile API to save its specific settings (currency, stores).  
3. **Platform Integration:**  
   * **Web Tools:** Web component  
   * **Flutter App:**  
     * **Native Implementation:** Build the non keycloak user management screens *natively* in Flutter. **Crucially**, this native UI must strictly adhere to the **Shared Design System**. It interacts directly with the **Backend User Profile API**. Tool-specific settings needed in the app are also built natively.  
     * **Question of the keycloak part, the webview solution is kind of disappointing**  
4. **Shared Design System**

author: teolemon

title: Potential GSOC applicants (repost from Slack)
text:
Potential GSOC applicants, just a comment:
- jumping on requesting assignment on any new issue is not a very good indication of focus.
- It’s not a race either. We have enough interesting issues for everyone.
- I’d rather have someone take on a more significant issue, and be able to deal with ambiguity, and document/mockup/discuss their way out of ambiguity rather than creating issues with limited or no tangible impact.
- You can go through the backlog, and find issues that are additive in terms of User Experience, and are well documented. If they are not, a good thing is to propose analysis, mockups and solutions. It’s as valuable as rushing to code something. We will evaluate of many criteria, code is only one of them.
- You can of course ask precise questions with enough context. “Please guide me” is too wide a question. We want to see your autonomy. “This is the API that seems the right one. Can you confirm it ?” or “Where’s the API to display XYZ ?” are valid questions
- Issue assignment is not a land grab, only one assignment at any given time. We value mergeability, craftsmanship, rather than having issues “vampirised” and having to un-assign weeks later. We will ask for updates, and un-assign the issues if no draft PR or progress update is available within a week

title: Best way to deal with ansible and git based configuration
text:
I'm working Hetzner configuration with ansible (see [PR](https://github.com/openfoodfacts/openfoodfacts-infrastructure/pull/475)).

I added a git_based_config role to checkout the -infrastructure repository on the server.

Now I'm working on sanoid configuration role. While I want to create service ans timers with ansible, as always, I want the sanoid / syncoid configurations to be symlinks to /opt/openfoodfacts-infrastructure/confs/<machine-name>/sanoid/{sanoid.conf,syncoid-args.conf}

I want this because it have the big advantage that we can make quick modifications on the servers and commit them.

But now at ansible creation time I'm faced with a small issue: I have the config files yet on my branch, while I need them on the server clone to be able to symlink them and test.

I envision this solution to this:
* as I run ansible playbook on a branch, I switch to this branch on the server clone
* I have to first commit and push my config files before running ansible-playbook, so that the server can get them

* maybe to avoid pitfalls, I might ensure:
  * that my branch is up to date with "develop" at least on the confs/my-machine folder, or break asking for an update
  * that distant server is not on yet another branch than this one or develop (work on two branches at the same time)

The only drawback is that at the end of operations, the server is left with its infrastructure clone pointing at this branch instead of develop.

Maybe it could be solved with a workflow at merge time but:
* It will need to understand which server to target based on file changes (feasible) 
* I'm really reluctant to give github workflow access to our proxmox hosts or full secrets in term of security

Useful pointer: https://openfoodfacts.github.io/openfoodfacts-infrastructure/explain-server-config-in-git/
author: alexgarel

title: Create few good practices for our infrastucture
text:
I created this page as a start: https://github.com/openfoodfacts/openfoodfacts-infrastructure/wiki

Everything can be discussed.

Here are some practices we could talk about:

0. Few and simple rules have a better chance to be followed.
We could prioritise as W3C use to, with keywords “MUST”, “MUST NOT”, “REQUIRED”, “SHALL”, “SHALL NOT”, “SHOULD”, “SHOULD NOT”, “RECOMMENDED”, “MAY”, and “OPTIONAL”.

1. Disable password authentication in favour of SSH keys
Using SSH key IS really simpler, I can write a quick documentation for beginners.

2. Disable root login over SSH

3. Working with root or not

4. Taking care of production resources: always using "nice" for scripts manually launched
Stéphane's tip: just use `nice ./mycommand -arg1 foo -arg2 bar` (`nice` default to lower the priority).

5. When possible, use techs that the majority of people knows
Our infrastructure is not so big. Low techs ensure it will be maintainable.
Example: good old scripts vs Ansible.

6. Standardize some core tools
Example: our standard distro is Linux Debian (well suited with point 5).

6. Basic tools to install on each machine
Example: htop, goaccess...

7. Log every sys action on /root/changelog.log

8. Add important commands beeing played to /root/changelog.log
So everybody knows what you have done concretly.

9. Backups?

10. Monitoring?

title: Idea: Adding StoryBook to Web Components
text: > Write stories once, reuse everywhere Hi Team, I am proposing to use [Storybook](https://storybook.js.org/) for developing and showcasing our web components. Why Storybook? - Streamlined Development: Build and test components in isolation, ensuring high quality before integration. - Improved Collaboration: Provides a visual catalog, making it easier for all stakeholders to understand and contribute. - Reusable Stories: Saves variations of components, which can be reused for documentation and testing. - [Storybook keeps track of every story](https://storybook.js.org/docs/get-started/why-storybook#storybook-keeps-track-of-every-story) - Rich Add-ons: Access tools for accessibility checks, performance insights, and more. Read more here on their official website: https://storybook.js.org/docs/get-started/why-storybook Storybook is an industry wide standard for showcasing the components. And there is a separate section on the Storybook official website showcasing StoryBook from all popular companies: https://storybook.js.org/showcase This tool aligns perfectly with our goals of efficiency and clarity across multiple projects. I believe integrating Storybook will enhance our workflow and make component reuse more seamless. Let me know your thoughts! cc: @Kout95 , @alexgarel , @teolemon Example StoryBook:

author: teolemon

title: Export data on a daily basis
text:
## Case 1: public exports
Some usages need a data export instead of using the API:
* as a reuser, when you want to understand what have been already collected
* as a reuser, when your use case does not need realtime API calls
* as a developer, when you want to test your code with real data

The export should allow:
* to read or manipulate the data with common tools
* to easily import these data into the dev environment

The export would be triggered once a day, with a cron job, not by the API.

## Case 2: private exports
Folksonomy Engine also offers the possibility to store private data (currently only through the API). Users could also want to export their own private data.

## Implementation

I think we should start by public exports, which are the most common need. 

As a start, we could export the data into CSV, which remains the easiest way to import data into many tools such as LibreOffice, Excel, etc. We should also provide the data model, to let people reuse the data into common data tools or databases. We should also provide a script allowing to import these data into a dev environment.
We could also provide a PostgreSQL dump to ease the import into the dev environment (but this one should not contain private data).

On a second step, which is not very urgent, we could:
* either export the data into other formats, such as Parquet or JSONL
* either provide scripts allowing to generate this formats locally
author: CharlesNepote

title: Conventions and UIs for grouped properties-values
text:
## Use cases

### Properties related to revisions
Sometimes we need to tag some versions of a product. For example, we would like to express that there is [a data issue on the revision 310 of a product](https://world.openfoodfacts.org/product/3017620422003/nutella-ferrero?rev=310), and this issue is now fixed.

### Reusing a group of property with different values
Sometimes we need to give context to some properties. For example we could want to monitor recalled products. But a product can be recalled more than one time. Having [`recalled_product=yes`](https://world.openfoodfacts.org/property/recalled_product) does not have much context: is it finished? when? For a given recall, we would like to know many more information related to this particular recall.

## Suggestion 1
We can multiply the properties like this:
* `data_issue_rev_310=Wrong serving size`
* `data_issue_rev_310=Fixed`
* `data_issue_rev_421=Non existing country`
* `product_recall_date_1=2020-06-01`
* `product_recall_country_1=France`
* `product_recall_date_2=2023-12-01`
* `product_recall_country_2=Italy`

## Suggestion 2
We can store the revision in the database.
`3749372783457:310` => `data_issue=Wrong serving size`

But we need to modify both the database and the interfaces. And this solution does not solve the problem when properties are reused.

## Suggestion 3
We can use the namespaces:
* `data_issue:rev_310=Wrong serving size`
* `data_issue:rev_310=Fixed`
* `product_recall:date:1=2020-06-01`
* `product_recall:country:1=France`
* `product_recall:date:2=2023-12-01`
* `product_recall:country:2=Italy`

We can even use the namespace to tag more things on a specific revision. Eg.
* `data_issue:rev_310:1=Wrong serving size`
* `data_issue:rev_310:2=Non existing countries`
* `data_issue:rev_310:1=Fixed`

With suggestion 3, we would only need to modify interfaces: we should be able to list all the data_issues, and not just the ones corresponding to `data_issue:rev_310`.
